response.answer_text: Amateurs study tactics, armchair generals study strategy, professionals study logistics The problem with this question is that the basic answer is not just “None of them” but “Wunderaffe are almost entirely about prioritising tactics over logistics and thus are fundamentally on the wrong path”. Further the Nazis were in serious trouble in any war that wasn’t won early because a big part of their ideology and reason for going to war, fighting for Lebensraum and to not let “inferior people” have their place, was inimical to good use of logistics. The very concept of a “Wunderwaffe” or “Wonder Weapon” is an idea that says that “This one thing will win the war”. If we look at almost all the game changers that weren’t simple iterations only one was an answer to what would win the war rather than an answer to the question “How can we work better together”. That one, the only one that actually fit the Wunderwaffen model was something the Nazis didn’t take seriously, in large part because it was based on “Jewish Science” and the Jews were people the Nazis had no place for and actively tried to exterminate.  The Trinity test of the Manhattan Project - an actual Wonder Weapon / Public Domain On a sidenote if Germany had still been fighting seriously in August 1945 then at least one and probably both of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombs would have been dropped on Germany. Wunderwaffen would have ended the war. I can think of a lot of projects and inventions that had a significant impact on the war - but almost all of them were answers to the question “How can we work together better”. Wunderwaffe on the other hand answer the question “What’s the one magic bullet that will prove our superiority?” And a magic bullet being expensive is a feature and not a bug if it’s about proving superiority. For that matter being hard to maintain demonstrates it’s complex - and makes people follow the Sunk Costs Fallacy; if they were the best and this is complex they wouldn’t have authorised that nonsense. If we look at the actual game-changing technologies in the war they are almost all answers to the question “how can we work together better” - or better logistics.  “Freeman’s Folly” - the wooden de Haviland Mosquito / Public Domain To illustrate the difference between an actually effective weapon and a Wunderwaffen we can compare the way the best engineers in Britain and Germany designed vehicles in the war would deliver about 1000kg of bombs to the other country fast enough to bypass most of the air defences. Representing Britain’s engineers "Freeman's Folly”, the “Wooden Wonder”, the “Timber Terror”, the de Havilland Mosquito (specifically the MkIV bomber) while representing the German Wunderwaffen was one of the few that actually got deployed and a precursor of the spacerace - the V-2 rocket. Cost: The Mosquito was literally made of wood and cost about 1/10 of a B-17 Flying Fortress. The V-2 cost as much as a high performance fighter - and the V-1 and V-2 project cost 50% more than the Manhattan Project. Advantage: MosquitoRange: Mk IV Mosquito: 3,780km. V-2: 320km. Advantage: Mosquito.Top Speed: Mosquito: 380mph. V-2: 3580mph. Advantage: V-2Payload: V-2: 1000kg (2200lbs). MK IV Mosquito: 4*500lb bombs or occasionally a less generally useful specialist variant carrying a 4000lb “blockbuster” bomb. Advantage: MosquitoAccuracy: Mosquito: WWII bomber, complete with Mk1 eyeballs to check if it hit its target. V-2: British counter-intelligence convinced Germany they were undershooting London by 10 miles so they retargeted 10 miles North. When they tried using the V-2 tactically to blow up a bridge actually in Germany 11 V-2s all missed, with misses ranging from 500 yards to 40 miles. Advantage: MosquitoSurvivability: The Mosquito was one of the safest bombers of the war - in large part because it was one of the fastest operational aircraft in the world when introduced, remained one of the fastest planes, and if it had to deal with a jet fighter, had a very low stall speed. Meanwhile the V-2 was on a one way trip - and is estimated to have killed more people building it than in the explosions where it hit. Advantage: Mosquito.What their enemies thought:“... those of us who were seriously engaged in the war were very grateful to Wernher von Braun. … From our point of view, the V-2 program was almost as good as if Hitler had adopted a policy of unilateral disarmament.” - Freeman Dyson“It makes me furious when I see the Mosquito. I turn green and yellow with envy. The British, who can afford aluminium better than we can, knock together a beautiful wooden aircraft that every piano factory over there is building, and they give it a speed which they have now increased yet again. What do you make of that? There is nothing the British do not have. They have the geniuses and we have the nincompoops.” - Herman GoringWhich would you rather have had on your side in a war? The tactical answer to the question “How can we reliably penetrate the enemy air defences, no matter the cost?” or the logistical answer to the question “Aluminium is a strategic resource? How good a plane can we make that uses wood instead?”  The impact of a single V-2. Not seen: Any military benefit / Public Domain Other Wunderwaffe were no better, prioritising tactics over strategy. The 188t Panzer VIII Maus might have the rear armour a Tiger II had from the front but it wasn’t going anywhere (or at least not without a ludicrous amount of fuel the Germans didn’t have and not over any bridges). The “waterfall design” of the Type XXI submarine would have solved a whole lot of tactical issues if it had been seaworthy - but as more than 95% of of the ones the Germans built weren’t the only logistical issues it solved were “How can the allies destroy over 100 U-Boats for no losses and never even firing a shot?” Even if they’d worked sonar and depth charges already existed; they’d have been a serious headache but weren’t unbeatable. Probably best was the Messerschmitt Me 262 jet fighter which was actually introduced in April 1944 and wasn’t enough to save Germany - especially not with German fuel shortages. It wasn’t even enough for Britain to bring the Gloster Meteor jet fighter, introduced two months later, out to play over the skies of Germany. Instead Britain used the Meteor to shoot down V-1 flying bombs, practice jet and anti-jet tactics, and occasionally to fly over allied territory and give the German jets a very nasty surprise.  Gloster Meteor being deployed in 1945 - not needed over Germany / Public Domain For war-changing and country saving projects we should look at the winning side and I’m going to point out three (other than the actual Wonder Weapon - the Manhattan Project). The Russian T-34. As a tank actually designed in WWII the T-34 was, one on one, very mediocre by the standards of wartime designs although it made all pre-war designs (German, Russian, and British alike) obsolete and in need of refitting at a minimum. But despite major shortcomings the T-34 was good enough even for the late war, and unlike the German tanks it was pretty reliable. It also allowed really effective use of Russia’s industry. It was a logistical triumph.The British Dowding System was the huge breakthrough. The Germans had Radar - but how do you get the intel from Radar into the hands of the pilots who need to use it? A system to first integrate the information provided by multiple Radar stations and the Royal Observer Corps and turning it into first a map and then something that could be sent to the pilots defending from the Luftwaffe. It’s not flashy - but it means that the existing defensive airforce could be used much more effectively so the fighters always had a numerical advantage. Another triumph of logistics.Bletchley Park - the largely British codebreaking camp based on the back of Polish work. Being able to read your enemy’s communications is huge. It’s not a Wunderwaffe because it’s not an actual weapon and of itself gets no one killed. But, even if you are concealing it and need plausible deniability, it is a massive game changer.I could have gone into more, especially to do with American industrial production, Liberty Ships, setting up a production line more than a mile long to build heavy bombers, and more. But that’s all boring logistics - and it’s a lot more fun for amateurs to study tactics. Logistically the Nazis were screwed, in large part because they were Nazis and enabling everyone to contribute and get the best information no matter their background was pretty much the opposite of what they were about.

Better diplomacy. The more I read and learn about the history of both world wars, the more I think the weopon that Germany was missing between 1914–1945 was a better diplomatic instinct that understood that soft power can be as effective as hard power, particularly when they are used together. (Teddy Roosevelt understood this, which is why he chose to “walk softly but carry a big stick“) In the first world war, Germany made so many mistakes from a diplomatic point of view. Their decision to invade France through Belgium brought the United Kingdom into the war, which meant the Royal Navy blockaded their ports and cut off their food supplies. This mistake led to the German decision to allow unlimited submarine warfare, in an effort to fight back against the British blockade, but this then caused friction with the United States. Then, to add insult to injury, the imperial German government made an even worse move, with their decision to send the Zimmerman telegram encouraging Mexico to take up arms against the United States. This brought the United States into the war. The German government was also terrible at mobilizing world opinion in their favor. The British naval blockade meant hunger and suffering in Germany, but the Germans were never able to get this message out to better support their need to have unlimited U Boat campaigns. Meanwhile, the allies took German atrocities in Belgium and made them into an international concern. In World War II, the Nazi war effort was hamstrung by a problem endemic to its nature, which was that weakness could never be acknowledged, and the winner will always be the one who projects the most strength (in their mind). Certainly, a weak leader can invite trouble by people who seek to take advantage of their weakness. But a leader who refuses to ever acknowledge mistakes or seek support risks alienating the people they wish to lead. For example, the Germans were not originally received poorly in places like the Ukraine, which had little love for their Soviet rulers. It was only after the Nazis insisted on treating the local population as subhuman that the people turned against them. In his diaries, Goebbels was aware that the Nazis were turning their conquered territories against Germany, but he didn’t know what to do about it and the the Nazi philosophy of “might makes right” didn’t leave anyone much room to maneuver.

“…one cannot deny that the Americans shipped over to us material without which we could not have equipped our armies, held in reserve or been able to continue the war.” —Soviet Marshal G.K. Zhukov Neither the USSR nor the UK stood a chance without access to massive quantities of US food, oil, aluminum, and other war materials. It’s worth pointing out that the USSR couldn’t feed itself in the 1930s during peacetime and the UK remained on food rationing until July, 1954. For additional background read Dima Vorobiev’s answer to Would the Soviet Union have survived the German invasion without American military aid? That being said, once America entered the war, the only way Germany could win WW2 was to neutralize shipping coming from the USA. If in 1938/1939, the Kriegsmarine had prioritized the development of submarines that nullified Allied ASW the resulting “Wunderwaffens” could have changed the outcome of the Battle Of The Atlantic. The Type 21 U-Boat had a streamlined hull, a nearly silent creep motor, an electric rapid torpedo-reloading system and 3 times the battery storage compared to standard U-boats. Its large batteries allowed it to travel underwater for 75 hours before needing a recharge. Had the Type 21 or something like it begun service in 1941/1942, Allied transports would have been defenseless. Most shipping between the USA and the UK/USSR would have been forced to stop. Without those ships, the UK and especially the Soviet Union wouldn’t have lasted long. “The only thing that ever really frightened me during the war was the U-boat peril.” —Winston Churchill

NONE. Yes, Germany had some truly innovative designs, and while it might have prolonged the end (and made it even bloodier) no wonder weapon would have changed the result. I’ll debunk a few of the mentions Jet Fighters like the ME-262, HE-163 etc would have faced Allied Jets such as the Meteor, MiG-9, Yak-15 and P-80. Germany was not the only country to have jet fighters (that would be the American P-59), they were only the first to use them in combat but that lead would only last 6 months as Allied jet fighters were not that far behind. Modern Uboats like the XXI. First of all the type XXI was far from a perfect design. It was underpowered which limited it speed and increased battery charge times. Moreover The battle of the Atlantic was a constant struggle, first Germany was winning, then the allies, then Germany then finally the allies. I don’t think anything would have changed, Germany would have sunk a lot more ships until the Allies developed a counter measure. It was quiet, but that was ineffective against active sonor systems. Wasserfall SAM…suffered a major flaw, it had no proximity fuse so it was entirely guided by LOS by the operator on the ground. That means without good viability (at night, in cloud cover, or blinded by smoke) the weapon was basically useless. You couldn't just saturate an area with rockets like you can with AAA fire. The Wasserfall was simply too limited by the technology of the day.

One can conclude, even without considering their catastrophic performance during WW2, that the three most expensive Wonder weapons projects were the gravest waste of Germany's industrial potential. The data on economics and effectiveness are not easy to find by googling even on German sources. A lot of digging. But before going to weapons, let’s take a look on their greatest doomed failure - the Atlantic Wall, "Festung Europa" - Fortress Europe. One may wonder why its idea came from from no other than Hitler, who approved Blitzkrieg tactics in France and Russia easily neutralizing Maginot and Stalin’s line in Ukraine. The whole Atlantic Wall project was a massive undertaking - and considered folly by many. It cost Germany an estimated 3.7 billion Deutschmarks and used 17 million cubic meters of concrete and 1.2 million tons of steel. Whilst formidable, the fortifications did not prevent the Allies from landing on D-Day, although well located firing positions were responsible for many of the British, American and Canadian losses in the first few days of fighting. Results: 10.000 Allies losses and a couple day fight. At a cost of 100 –200K per plane (1943–1940) 20.000 TO 40.000 U88 or Me-109 could be built and triple war production.  V1 and V-2 Rockets Only 30% reached their targets killing few London civilians and costing twice as much as the Manhattan project The V-1 according to Wiki (thanks to flyboy for gathering this data) cost was 5090 RM which equals $2044 US dollars during WW2, roughly $34,700 in todays dollars. It took 350 man hours to build so you could argue that each man hour is about 14 RM. British Response to V1 and V2 - The National Archives The people of Britain called the V1 missiles ‘Buzz Bombs’ or ‘Doodlebugs’. The first was dropped at Swanscombe in Kent on 13 June 1944 and the last one at Orpington in Kent on 27 March 1945. During that time, 6,725 were launched at Britain. Of these, 2,340 hit London, causing 5,475 deaths, with 16,000 injured. Three lines of defence were put in place against the missiles: fighter planes over the English coast, anti-aircraft batteries in Kent and barrage balloons around London. These were successful in destroying 3,500 V1 missiles. V2 rockets were first launched against England in September 1944. Over the next few months, nearly 1,400 struck London. They were less accurate than V1 missiles, but since they travelled at the speed of sound, and so made no warning noise before impact, it was almost impossible to defend against them.  Land Battles Fortunately the Maus tank project came too late and was aborted. It was an even more bizarre animal than the Char 2.   Char 2C: France's Super Heavy Tank (And Maybe the Biggest Ever)  Battleships.  German POWs from one of the battleships.  It was not only a military disaster. Let's next look at an economic effect, which is even more striking, by comparing it's cost with costs of airplanes and I boats. The work on the hull construction began on October 24 and the ship was launched on April 1, 1939. During the launch ceremony the official name of the new battleship was finally revealed. The vessel was to be named after Großadmiral Alfred von Tirpitz, the father of the Imperial German Navy. The battleship was christened by the late Admiral’s daughter, Frau von Hassel. Airplanes The man-hour cost for the Messerschmitt Bf 109 dropped to 4000 with the 'G' model, slightly more than took for the Fw 190, to be produced. It gives us a striking ratio of 3600 Bfs (15.000 in 1944) for a single ship, or more than Germany’s total airplane production in WW2. Me-262s were A-1a variants. So that doesn't tell us much about airframe production cost. I have historical cost data for Ju-88 airframe so we can use that for an example. RM 216,523. Production cost for Junkers built Ju-88A4 during 1940.RM 139,274. Production cost for Junkers built Ju-88A4 during 1943.Late production Ju-88 costs one third less then early production aircraft. Given the cheaper jet engines the Me 262 may even have been cheap Hence a Me 262 airframe ay RM87,400 must have been worth just under 6000 man hours. But it was too late to have any effect and its killing ratio was below cost ratio.  Generally, costs were sharply reduced towards 1944. Me 262 airframe was RM87,400 worth just under 6000 man hours. At the end Me 109K4 got down to 1000 hours per airframe but was closer to 2000 the year before. It also was around 6000 hours in 1940. There is not necessarily a direct relationship between man hours and costs as costs may factor in use of precious raw materials better or R+D costs that are being amortised.  Conclusion. Without quixotic projects brought about by Hitler, Germany could have at least doubled its conventional fighting arsenal. And this without mentioning that 90% of Manhattan project scientists were European Jews. But that is another story.

Nuclear bombs. The problem for Germany was that the allies were producing obscene amounts of equipment and they surrounded the Nazis and ruled the waves. This meant that while the allies could use materials from all over the world the Nazis were limited to using materials in Europe. All of the traditional Nazi Wunderwaffe (tanks, jets, missiles, submarines) needed to be mass produced and they needed high quality metals. The Nazis didn’t have the raw resources to mass produce them. The most obvious manifestation of this issue was in jet aircraft. The British Meteor was more reliable than the Nazi ME262 because the Nazis didn’t have access to the materials needed to make the alloys required for reliable jet engines. The British didn’t have to use the Meteor against 262s since allied propeller aircraft like Mustangs and Spitfires already overwhelmed the 262 with sheer numbers. The Nazis only needed a few nuclear bombs to win the war. While they didn’t have enough materials to build 10,000 jet fighters and 100 Type 21 submarines they could have built enough nukes to turn Southeast England, parts of Russia and large Allied troop concentrations to ash. Nuclear bombs would have crippled Britain and Russia and inflicted such huge casualties that even the USA could have easily been forced out of the war by public pressure. A single Nazi Type 21 sub could even have been loaded with a nuke and sent on a nuclear kamikaze mission against the US east coast.

None. But I disagree with the assessment of most people here that Wunderwaffen were foolish in the first place. Germany never had a realistic chance of going toe to toe with Britain, the Free French, the Soviets and the Americans while relying on conventional or even qualitatively superior conventional weapons. The odds against Germany were roughly 10 to 1 and to even those one needs miracles and miracle weapons. Type XXI u-boats in their last configuration (faster underwater than above, beyond effect speed of an escort vessel using sonar, employing burst radio transmissions and auto-loading torpedo tubes) could have been available significantly sooner (1940 or 41) including most technology needed. None. They actually consumed vast amounts of financial and industrial resources for little gain. The Me-262 wouldn’t have stopped the bomber onslaught. There was simply far too many bombers and production of pilots and personnel to operate them could be kept for years. Type XXI submarines could make the battle for the Atlantic much more longer and costly but it would never be able to destroy the ever increasing allied shipping build up. Horten Brothers flying wings needed on board computers to be flyable and viable. V-1 rockets had a big psychological effects but the reality is that they couldn’t produce a guidance system to achieve a direct hit against an specific target. Only in the era of GPS this could be done. V-2 rockets had the same issue, without in-flight correction capabilities a direct strategic hit couldn’t be achieved. V-3 would never have worked without a computerized detonation system. Something that I don’t think has ever been invented. Tanks such as the Standard series could have done the war much costlier, but they were heavy and engines would have had a hard time achieving the power and torque needed for them. The only way Germany could have won the war is having the capability of producing enough minerals and fuel to keep their forces supplied with good equipment and provisions. They did make breakthroughs in producing synthetic fuel. But it just wasn’t enough, either primary materials or productive infrastructure.

None of them. The problem Germany had wasn’t one that could be solved by building better weapons. You need trained crews to use those weapons, fuel to power them, parts to fix them, etc. Germany was losing a huge amount of manpower and resources. They had nowhere they could effectively build weapons before deploying them. Let’s say they built all the Me-262s they wanted. They’d already lost air superiority, where would they train pilots when most of the country was constantly traversed by Allied long-range fighter-bombers? Meanwhile, both the US and Russia have tons of available manpower, resources and safe areas for manufacturing. The US is able to supply both Russia and Britain via cheap, easy-to-build freighters called “Liberty ships” - my grandfather served on one of them - and even during the worst of the war was able to keep building more to replace their losses. Interestingly, even while we were at war with Japan, the Japanese navy didn’t interfere with US supplying Russia, because they didn’t want Russia entering the war against Japan! Meanwhile, the US is using Britain as the world’s largest aircraft carrier, building a ton of supplies there that the Germans can no longer reach since they lost their offensive air power during the Battle of Britain. Maybe, just maybe, the way the Germans could have won the war would have been to put more resources into unrestricted submarine warfare earlier in the war - that’s not really a “Wunderwaffen” though, but just a reallocation of resources. But I kind of doubt it, and I don’t know that they could have provided those resources even if they wanted to. Germany was just not that much of a naval power.

I think it’s fitting during this corona-lockdown period to be reminded that both sides in the war actually did have an arsenal of secret chemical-biological “wunderwaffen” which might have radically changed the course of the war if they were ever used: By the end of the war, the germans had access to a huge stockpile of Sarin gas, which might have upended watershed operations such as D-day if it had been distributed among regular Wehrmacht infantry units. The British on the other hand had weaponized anthrax and had deadly plans for its use if the war had escalated just that extra bit. Why both sides refrained remains partially unknown: a notion of ‘mutual assured destruction’ avant la lettre might have played a role, so might have Hitlers personal confrontation with poison gas in WWI or simply the inability of the Wehrmacht to develop gas masks for their horses. Anyhow, my post should drive home the observation that WWII is not a good stage to have a radically different outcome depending on the introduction (or not) of a deus-ex-machina-wunderwaffe on either side: none of the combattants seem to have been already fully comitted, despite the rethoric about ‘total war’ etc. E.g. if the Germans would have had jet-engines sooner, then the British could have dropped their anthrax cakes in response and from there you have to theorize in a new reality where already more than 2 factors change at once, making it impossible to track who might have ended on top in such a more drawn-out, tragic conflict.
